content_clusters.topic: Employee Shift Viewing and Attendance Marking
content_clusters.consolidation_notes: Single article covering employee-facing shift visibility and check-in/check-out workflow. No PRD enrichment needed.

Articles 20409443906321 and 14284565450257 cover shift creation workflow. PRD 3701112979 enriches with multi-work-center support, pagination, filtering, and notification enhancements. Navigation map entry 'Scheduling' is primary entry point for this workflow.
Article 14284791485329 covers copying and pasting shifts across employees and date ranges. Article 26807457737873 covers bulk deletion. Both use similar selection and confirmation patterns.
Single article covering Schedule Planner feature for simultaneous multi-employee shift assignment. Distinct from individual shift creation.
Single article covering manager actions on existing shifts: edit check-in/out times, clear attendance, delete records, create leave requests, reassign shifts.
Single article on interview scheduling with calendar integration (Gmail/Outlook). Distinct from employee shift scheduling; included in batch as provided.

Articles 18001047040913 and 14313098291601 both cover work center creation and management. PRD 3701112979 adds multi-work-center mapping for schedulers and offices, enhancing the base setup workflow with enterprise-scale support.

Article 14313098291601 covers basic shift creation and management. PRD 3720938008 extends with split shift capability (multiple shifts per day). PRD 3701112979 adds multi-work-center selection, filtering, and pagination for enterprise scheduling.

Article 14284706643729 covers attendance report viewing and editing. PRD 3720938008 adds per-shift attendance tracking for split shifts. PRD 3701112979 adds notification system for schedule changes affecting attendance.
Grouped tickets addressing inability to define, create, and manage split/multiple shifts, including overtime scheduling and check-in/out constraints with multiple shifts.
Grouped feature gaps around bulk import/export of shift schedules and work timing configurations via Excel or spreadsheet formats.
Grouped issues where attendance records, leave requests, and shift data interact unexpectedly, including automatic deletion and leave calculation problems.
Single ticket addressing lack of native shift schedule publication mechanism for administrators.
Grouped strict validation rules preventing legitimate check-ins and lack of location-based validation for biometric attendance.
Grouped issues around lack of granular shift visibility, center-wide views, and configurable permission controls for line managers.
Single ticket addressing incomplete audit logs for shift scheduler entities in admin panel.
Single ticket addressing Safari 10.1 compatibility issue with URLSearchParams parameter parsing.
Single ticket addressing complex interdependent overtime and work week settings affecting historical calculations.

Three tickets describing failures in time validation: overlapping shifts not blocked, date picker issues causing day offset, and inability to handle midnight-spanning shifts. All affect scheduling accuracy.

Three tickets describing system constraints around retroactive scheduling and configuration changes. System prevents shifts before work center assignment, prioritizes historical assignments, and has midnight boundary issues for 24-hour shifts.
Single ticket describing intentional design constraint where modified shifts are not transferred during copy operations.

Three tickets describing filtering and view rendering problems: OR logic instead of AND, inability to relate work timing IDs to attendance, and missing filter/display capabilities in mobile and scheduler views.
Three tickets describing reporting gaps: Excel export lacks visual consistency, overtime reports missing cumulative totals, and shift schedule logs lack clear visual indicators of modifications.
Single ticket describing inability to configure granular deductions for time-based attendance policy violations (partial day deductions for tardiness/early departure).
Two tickets describing employee-facing gaps: no mechanism to download personal attendance records, and leave policy cannot account for shift-based days-off in working days calculations.

product_context.title: PRD: Split shifts
product_context.why_built: Businesses like cafes and retail shops need employees to work during different peak periods based on customer footfall. Split shifts allow optimized staffing by having employees work morning hours, take a break, and return for afternoon or evening coverage. This is common in retail, cafes, healthcare, and hospitality where coverage is needed during different parts of the day with breaks between work segments.
key_design_decisions: Maximum 2 shifts per employee per day in Phase 1 (expandable based on customer feedback)
No overlap allowed with shifts on same day, day before, or day after
Cannot schedule second shift if day off already exists on that day
Each shift treated independently for all attendance calculations (late/early/absent, occurrences)
Back-to-back shift checkout handling with configurable window (Phase 2) to manage transitions between shifts
Biometric check-in works with existing threshold logic for each shift
No overlap validation across same day, day before, and day after shifts to prevent scheduling conflicts
Day off presence blocks split shift creation to respect employee rest days
Each shift tracked independently for attendance calculations (late, early, absent, occurrences)
Biometric check-in uses existing threshold logic per shift independently

product_context.title: PRD: Shift scheduler enhancement
product_context.why_built: Schedulers and employees needed better communication about schedule changes. Without notifications, important updates about shifts, work centers, and leave impacts went unnoticed, causing confusion and missed work. This enhancement provides comprehensive notifications, multi-work-center support, and improved enterprise-scale scheduling capabilities.
key_design_decisions: Multi-work-center support: schedulers and offices can be mapped across multiple work centers
Work center dropdown with 'All' selected by default for multi-work-center schedulers, single work center auto-selected for single-center schedulers
Pagination values: 25, 50, 100, 150 employees per page with persistence across sessions
Email and mobile notifications for schedule changes, employee changes, and leave conflicts
Shift reassignment generates two notifications: one for deleted (old employee), one for assigned (new employee)
Same office mapped to multiple work centers avoids need for duplicate office names
React frontend replacing Ember for improved performance and scalability
Multi-work-center mapping allows schedulers and offices to be assigned to multiple work centers, reducing redundancy and improving flexibility
Pagination options (25, 50, 100, 150 employees per page) persist across sessions for consistent user experience
Approved leave cells shown greyed out with leave type to provide visual clarity
Weekend/holiday shifts displayed with clear visual distinction

detected_integrations.description: Employees view shifts and mark attendance via mobile app. Managers create and manage schedules on mobile. Push notifications sent to employees for shift updates and publications.

Shift Scheduler is tightly coupled with Attendance module for check-in/check-out, leave management, and attendance record creation. Issues with shift publication, multiple shifts, and attendance validation directly impact both modules.
Work centers are core entities for organizing shift scheduling. Schedulers and offices are mapped to work centers. Employees belong to single work center.

When a leave request is approved for a period with published shifts, those shifts become invalid and the scheduler is notified. Day off presence blocks split shift creation. Leave type is displayed visually in shift scheduler.
Shift scheduling feeds into payroll calculations for deductions, overtime, and leave accruals. Gaps in deduction configuration and leave policy logic affect payroll accuracy.
When an employee is inactivated, deleted, or offboarded, all future shift schedules are deleted and the scheduler is notified. Employee activation status affects shift scheduling eligibility.

Email and mobile notifications are sent to schedulers when schedules are deleted, unpublished due to leave conflicts, or when employees are changed. Mobile notifications are sent to employees when shifts are published or changed.
Interview scheduling integrates with Gmail and Outlook calendars for candidate interview bookings.
Tracks work hours from shifts. Handles check-in/out for each shift independently in split shift scenarios.
Biometric check-in works with existing threshold logic for each shift independently. For split shifts, check-in/check-out is tracked separately per shift.

Shift Scheduler provides shift timings that determine expected check-in/check-out windows. Attendance system records actual check-in/check-out times and compares against shift schedules to calculate late, early, and absent status. For split shifts, attendance is tracked independently per shift.
Shift Scheduler role must be assigned to personnel before they can manage work centers and create shift schedules. Role permissions control access to shift scheduling features.
Work timings are configured in Attendance Settings. Office locations are defined in Company Settings and mapped to work centers. The same office can be reused across multiple work centers.
For split shifts, deduction policies apply late/absent deductions per shift independently. Hourly rate vs daily wage calculations must account for multiple shifts per day.
Overtime (T&P adjustments) cannot be scheduled with multiple shifts. Work week configuration retroactively impacts historical overtime calculations, affecting payroll processing.
Attendance system lacks location validation for biometric check-ins, preventing enforcement of shift location constraints.
Shift scheduler audit logging was historically incomplete (resolved Oct 2023). System now tracks shift modifications but lacks visual indicators in UI.
Line manager permissions in attendance module cannot be configured or restricted by super admins, creating inflexible access control.

Overtime policies are evaluated at check-in time relative to shift publication and employee policy assignment. System correctly handles policy application timing but lacks granular notification filtering.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform cannot define, create, or manage split shifts and multiple shifts per employee per day. Users cannot schedule overtime (T&P adjustments) when employees have multiple published shifts, and the attendance system lacks flexibility for non-standard shift scenarios like 24-hour shifts or back-to-back shifts. Check-in/check-out is restricted to predefined time windows, preventing accurate logging across shift boundaries.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: Split shifts feature was launched with intentional restrictions on overtime scheduling with multiple shifts. The system was designed with single check-in/check-out per shift as a core constraint.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The shift scheduler interface has multiple UI defects: filters do not properly update shift bar graphs and statistical visualizations (number of shifts/total hours), the 'change all' and 'reset' button logic does not support multiple shifts, date information fails to display consistently in the edit shift dialog, and manager override functionality breaks when employees have consecutive shifts due to strict time validation rules.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: The team strategically decided not to implement comprehensive 'all' and 'reset' functionality for shift scheduling. Strict time validation was intentionally designed to prevent overlapping time entries.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform lacks bulk import functionality for shift schedules from Excel or spreadsheet formats, requiring manual individual shift entry. Users cannot export work timing configurations or shift schedules in Excel format. While a 'Schedule planner' alternative exists, it does not provide the direct file import functionality users require.

The platform has design constraints where active shifts (today/yesterday) are not displayed as consolidated blocks in attendance reports. When employees are on leave, the system automatically removes attendance records without transparent user notification. The leave management system cannot automatically adjust leave days based on published shift schedules or company-specific working day policies. Published shift details are deleted during employee work center reassignments, even when check-in records exist for the current day.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: Active shifts are intentionally not consolidated. Automatic attendance record removal during leave is a design decision. The system cannot differentiate between future and current shift records during employee status changes.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform lacks a native mechanism for administrators to formally publish and distribute draft shift schedules to employees, creating manual communication overhead for scheduling teams.

The attendance system enforces strict validation rules requiring shifts to be published as working days before check-ins are accepted. Check-ins received before shift publication or after shift status changes are automatically rejected. The platform lacks robust location validation for biometric check-ins and cannot prevent employees from checking in at locations different from their scheduled shift location, creating potential time and attendance tracking discrepancies.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: Strict shift publication requirement is an intentional validation rule. Location-based validation was not implemented as a core feature.

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform lacks granular shift visibility controls: line managers cannot filter shifts within a single work center to view only their reporting employees, the platform does not support center-wide shift schedule views preventing employees from seeing colleague shifts within the same location, and there are no configurable permission settings for line manager roles in the attendance module. Line managers have default edit access that cannot be restricted by super admins.

The admin panel has a bug preventing the display of complete audit logs for shift scheduler and hrcore entities. This limits the ability to track and validate historical shift and attendance data within the 90-day retention period, impacting compliance and troubleshooting capabilities.

The platform has a browser compatibility constraint with older Safari versions (Safari 10.1), which exhibits inconsistent behavior with URLSearchParams. This limits the platform's ability to handle query parameter parsing reliably across all browser versions, potentially causing application errors.

The platform's overtime and work week configuration involves multiple interdependent settings that can retroactively impact historical shift calculations. Users may find it challenging to understand how changes in work week configuration affect past overtime calculations, creating potential confusion during configuration and troubleshooting.

The platform lacks intuitive mechanisms for schedulers to quickly create shifts for individual employees and comprehensively edit shifts across different states (draft and published). Creating or modifying shifts requires multiple steps or lacks straightforward quick-entry interfaces.

what_to_watch_out_for.theme: Time Range Validation & Midnight Boundary Issues
what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform lacks robust time range validation and date handling mechanisms. The system permits overlapping work timings without warnings, lacks proper date picker logic causing automatic day offset in check-in/check-out times, and cannot handle time entries spanning midnight. These issues create scheduling conflicts, inconsistent time calculations, and force manual shift splitting.

The system enforces strict temporal constraints that prevent retroactive scheduling and configuration changes. Shifts cannot be created or modified for dates before an employee's work center assignment, historical shift assignments persist and override current work week configurations preventing recalculation, and 24-hour shift configurations are complicated by midnight boundary resets.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: System maintains data integrity by preventing modifications to periods before employee assignment and prioritizing historical accuracy

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The shift copying functionality intentionally does not transfer modified shifts, preventing direct duplication of altered schedules. This is a deliberate system design choice to maintain schedule integrity.
what_to_watch_out_for.design_rationale: Prevents accidental propagation of modified shifts and maintains schedule integrity

what_to_watch_out_for.limitation: The platform has multiple filtering and view rendering deficiencies. View filters operate with OR logic instead of AND logic, preventing precise filtering of day-off shifts by office parameters. The system cannot relate work timing IDs to attendance actions, limiting dynamic shift information display. Mobile app and scheduler views lack employee filtering by office assignment, precise late employee identification, and day name displays.

The platform's reporting and export capabilities lack visual consistency and comprehensive data presentation. Excel exports of shift schedules lack visual formatting matching the native table view, overtime reports cannot generate cumulative totals, and shift schedule logs lack clear visual indicators distinguishing original assignments from subsequent modifications.

The platform lacks bulk operation capabilities for shift scheduling and overtime management. There is no native UI for bulk deleting historical overtime requests with specific status and date range filters, and no mass upload functionality for shift scheduling. Organizations with large employee populations must use workarounds like copy schedule or schedule planner, which do not fully address bulk workflow needs.

The Bayzat payroll system lacks granular deduction configuration for time-based attendance policy violations. The platform cannot automatically calculate and apply partial day deductions for employee tardiness or early departures, requiring manual payroll adjustments.

The platform lacks granular notification filtering and comprehensive audit logging. Notifications are sent system-wide without considering organizational structure or reporting relationships, and the shift scheduler module historically lacked user-level audit logs showing who published or modified shifts (resolved October 2023).

The platform restricts employee self-service capabilities and has flawed leave calculations for shift-based schedules. Employees cannot download their personal attendance records without administrative intervention, and the leave policy using working days cannot automatically account for scheduled shift days-off, preventing accurate leave tracking for employees with complex shift schedules.
